description: From Middle English revolucion, borrowed from Old French revolucion, from Late Latin revolūtiōnem, accusative singular of revolūtiō (“the act of revolving; revolution”), from Latin revolvō (“roll back, revolve”).

entries.meaning: A political upheaval in a government or state characterized by great change.
The removal and replacement of a government, especially by sudden violent action.
Rotation: the turning of an object around an axis, one complete turn of an object during rotation.
examples: The ratio between the speeds of revolution of wheel and disc is substantially equal to the reciprocal of the ratio between the diameter of the wheel and the diameter of the mean contact circle on the disc.

entries.meaning: In the case of celestial bodies, the traversal of one body along an orbit around another body.
A sudden, vast change in a situation, a discipline, or the way of thinking and behaving.
A round of periodic changes, such as between the seasons of the year.
Consideration of an idea; the act of revolving something in the mind.
